body_text.text: Elastic fibers, the most resilient elements of connective tissue, account for skin 26 distensibility, flexibility and integrity. [1] [2] These fibers are predominantly comprised (90%) of 27 elastin, a protein with intricate ultrastructure. 3 Dermatological conditions characterized by 28 elastic tissue anomaliesexhibit increased, decreased or abnormal structure of elastic tissue in 29 the dermis, which alters skin distensibility, resulting in individual papules. 4 Perifollicular 30 elastolysis is a rare disorder characterized by focal, marked decrease in elastic fibers within 31 1-3 mm wrinkled folliculocentric papules. 5,6 Herein, we describe two cases of perifollicular 32 elastolysis with unique inframammary distribution.

Case 1 35 A 37-year-old Caucasian woman without prior dermatologic history presented to our 36 clinic for evaluation of similar skin lesions in her axillae, groin and inframammary areas. The 37 latter region was of greatest concern to her.Lesions began a few years prior as "small bumps" 38 without symptoms. She did, however, note occasional "pimples" in these regions exacerbated 39 by sweating. No treatments had been attempted. Family history, social history, and review of 40 systems were non-contributory/negative.

FIGREF0.text: 41Physical examination was remarkable for numerous, monomorphic skin-colored42 folliculocentric <3mm papules in the bilateral inframammary region (Figures 1), as well as in 43 the inguinal, bilateral upper thigh, and mons pubis regions. She was initially diagnosed with 44 folliculitis without evidence of scarring and started on a regimen of 5% benzoyl peroxide 45 wash once daily. However, at her three-month follow-up visit, she reported minimal 46 improvement of the lesions under her breasts. Repeat examination continued to reveal 47 scattered skin-colored folliculocentric papules. Two 4mm punch biopsies were performed of 48 representative papules under the left and right breast. Histopathologic examination revealed 49 dilated infundibula with sparse perifollicular fibrosis (Figure 2). Elastic tissue staining 50 (Vierhoff-van Gieson) showed an abnormal pattern of elastic fiber distribution within the 51 upper dermis, mainly in the papillary dermis around the dilated follicular infundibula with 52 elastolysis(Figure 3). Overall, the clinicopathologic features were most consistent with 53 perifollicular elastolysis. The patient was empirically treated with topical tretinoin 0.025% 54 cream nightly and she reported improvement in appearance of the lesions after 3 months. In-55 person follow-up was deferred due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

FIGREF2.text: Physical examination was remarkable for erythematous plaques with mild micaceous 64 scale of the upper and lower extremities accounting for 7% body surface area, attributable to 65 chronic plaque psoriasis. Additionally, the bilateral inframammary region had monomorphic 66 < 3mm, skin-colored, and evenly distributed papules (Figure 4). Acneiform papules and 67 hyperpigmented macules were also present on the bilateral thighs and interspersed on the 68 inframammary folds. A single 4 mm punch biopsy was performed of a papule under the right 69 breast. Histopathology demonstrated patulous follicular infundibula associated with reduction 70 in elastic fiber density, as well as elastic fiber abnormalities centered around the follicle 71 (clumping, thickening and shortening/fragmentation of fibers). Overall, this was most 72 consistent with a diagnosis of perifollicular elastolysis. Perifollicular elastolysis is on a continuum 82 with acne vulgaris. Some studies suggest that elastase-producing strains of Staphylococcus 83 epidermidis and Cutibacterium acne (formerly Propionibacterium acnes) found in hair 84 follicles are implicated in the etiopathogenesis. 5,6 However, in another study by Dick et al., 85 no elastase activity was noted in strains of P. acnes and S. epidermidis found on the skin 86 surface of 10 patients with anetoderma-like scars from acne vulgaris. Instead, they suggest 87 that tissue necrosis is caused by leukocytes involved in the inflammatory phase of the 88 condition with regeneration consisting of collagenous scar formation devoid of elastin fibers. 8 89 In either case, the observed histopathology demonstrates total or subtotal absence of elastic 90 fibers surrounding hair follicles, paucity of inflammation, nonspecific vascular findings, and 91 collagen irregularities. 4 92The differential diagnosis of perifollicular elastolysis can be broad, including 93 clinically similar pathologies or those with decreased elastic tissue on histopathology. A 94 thorough differential diagnosis is presented inTable 1. 9, 10 Perifollicular elastolysis was 95 diagnosed on account of follicular involvement (only mid-dermal elastolysis, lichen 96 planopilaris, and milia are in nature). The lack of inflammation on pathology ruled out lichen 97 planopilaris. Clinical appearance and pathology similarly ruled out milia or disorders on the 98 keratosis pilaris spectrum. 99 Perifollicular elastolysis occurs on the upper back, upper chest, or upper arms and 100 presents as 1-3 mm round-to-oval papules that are white, yellow or skin-colored. 4,7 In our 101 cases, the patients uniquely presented with lesions on or near the breasts. To our knowledge, 102 this is the first report of perifollicular elastolysis on the breast or in intertriginous distribution. 103 However, we imagine this finding may be underreported. Clinician awareness of lesions in 104 this area of the body whereis important to keep this condition (and other elastolysis disorders) 105 in the differential diagnosis.106Although many patients undergo acne-related treatment for this condition, the papules 107 are recalcitrant. Some authors suggest this condition is untreatable. 7 It is important for the 108 clinician to recognize, diagnose, and, perhaps most importantly, counsel patients on the 109 etiology of this condition and its lack of response to treatment, thus preventing unnecessary 110 frustration and expense related to futile management strategies.
